title: 114_s1885
content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veteran for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for covered veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system of the Department of Veterans Affairs at six selected locations. The program established by the "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" provides intensive case management interventions for covered veterans at six selected locations, including cities with high homeless veteran populations and suburban or rural settings. The Secretary selects locations with strong Department-community organization coordination for housing and social services. Intensive case management interventions are provided to at least 20 covered veterans at each location. The Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015 provides intensive case management interventions for covered veterans at selected locations, including assistance with housing, benefits, and services to improve stability and healthcare appropriateness. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will start the intensive case management program by September 1, 2016, as required by section 2067(a). A report on the program's assessments, including types of interventions and housing status of veterans, must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by December 1, 2018. The report on the intensive case management program for veterans must include their housing status, employment status before and after receiving intervention, use of health care services from the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related costs incurred. The report on the intensive case management program for veterans must include housing and employment status, use of health care services, costs incurred, number of veterans receiving interventions, and Department costs for carrying out the program. The report must include an estimate of costs the Department would have incurred for health care services to covered veterans without intensive case management interventions, broken down by locations. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help homeless veterans transition to permanent housing and prevent veterans at risk of homelessness from losing their housing. Grants will be awarded to carry out this program. The Secretary prioritizes organizations for grants based on their ability to provide case management services, especially those offering transitional housing services. Extra priority is given to organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding for transitional housing and convert facilities to provide permanent housing. The organization prioritizes grants for providing permanent housing that meets quality standards under the United States Housing Act of 1937. Conversion of facilities from transitional to permanent housing is considered compliant with grant terms. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. Expansion of housing assistance program for veterans by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for homeless veterans, those at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families. This includes acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy.
